review_title: Expected to do my job and my supervisors job, with very little pay or respect.
pros: Great to gain experience right out of college. students are good kids for the most part
cons: working 60+ hour weeks with very little pay and no time off. upon requesting time off, was expected to give a detailed report of why I needed off. was promoted to assistant director before I left and was not given a cent of salary increase though my job duties doubled. was not allowed to take off during summer season as this was our busiest season but my super was nowhere to be found...she did not follow the same rules she outlined for her workers.  since I did not have a "family" my personal time was regarded as insignificant. was not allowed to share with coworkers that I lived with my fiance. administration is a JOKE, they care more about money than they do the students. i was appalled at how they handled university business.

review_title: Complete departments shut down, tremendous amount of employee layoffs, no job stability, students overcharged and only m
pros: Staff that is left care deeply about the students and try to compensate for lack of departments that no longer exist.  In spite of negative SACS reports people give 150%.
cons: No place to refer students with problems-no Counseling center, no job security,  must continually lay off employees to meet debt repayments.  No communication from above and poor leadership and bad management and a Board that is uninformed of activities.  Limited course selections and retention is at an all time low.

review_title: Good job right out of college.
pros: The is a great job to have if you are undecided on a career after you graduate. The hours can be pretty flexible depending on where you work, and the  atmosphere is relaxed.
cons: Promotions are few and far between. Pay is not great, especially if you have large student loan payments, rent, etc...not much money left after all of your bills are paid.

review_title: The values of this company are a mask for the shady management.
pros:
Direct coworkers are great and have the same vision.
Student body is great.
Mission of the University is great.
Other staff and faculty have integrity.
cons:
Lots of overtime but company finds any way possible not to pay overtime.
Upper management receives a nice cut of donations and compensation plans but do not contribute to the growth of the company just work towards their own gain. It is all politics and power games.
The values of the university are only reflected most of professors and staff but upper management lead and live in a way that is contrary.
Human Resources is not there for the employees but to cover for upper management.
When you first start you are given the responsibilities which were discussed in your job description but soon enough there are extra responsibilities which should constitute an entirely new job position or are the responsibilities of your supervisor that fall on you.
There is really no direction for promotion, and the compensation for the amount of stress from the job is not balanced.
More results are expected but no incentives or resources are given to accomplish such results.

pros: My first year (out of 3) was a positive teaching experience.  Students made all the difference during the first two years.
cons: No training for objective such as advising students, administrative responsibilities. Guarantied support that  promised was never provided when asked to take on more responsibility.   There was not equality amongst faculty. There was constant fear based management which created a hostile work environment.   No job security and many wolf's in sheep's clothing.  Proceed with caution.

pros:
I have worked here for over two years now and have loved many of the people I work with and the many holidays we get off. This is about as far as the pros go for me. You never have to take work home. 

I believe my boss genuinely cares about me and our office members, but that isn't enough to shield us from the executive office's poor decisions.
cons:
Employee turnover rates are high for both faculty and staff so you'll see many new faces come and go. University enrollment and retention has been low in recent years, so HBU is in a bad place right now. All departments are being asked to slash budgets and many faculty on contracts are not having their contracts renewed (a.k.a. layoffs). We were informed that there will be no annual raises this year, but that doesn't make a difference because the normal raises are so small that you basically end up getting under $100 more per year IF you do well in your performance reviews. This is especially devastating when you consider that most entry-level positions pay you less here than at other Universities. Money doesn't seem to be well spent here - that is why you hear about new athletics facilities and classroom buildings but have students living in mold-infested dorms that flood and are falling apart.

Focusing back on the employee experience - don't expect a ton of opportunities for growth or salary increases here. Use this job as a stepping stone to get into better positions at Universities that are growing. I've experienced and witnessed the way HBU prioritizes numbers and dollar signs over people and I can tell you that the culture they "promote" is not the same as the one that exists. Since there are so many staff members who leave, and since HBU doesn't have the funds to hire more people, many lower-level staff members are overworked and it shows. For me, and for many of my peers both in my office and elsewhere, the only things that is sure to grow while you're here is the length of your job description.
